abstract.p: David E Mandelbaum letter points out that Serbs finally rose up against Slobodan Milosevic because he ruined their economy, not when 'all' he was doing was carrying out barbaric ethnic cleansing in Kosovo and Bosnia (S)

block.p: As we celebrate the overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic, it is important to step back and realize what we are celebrating. As pointed out by Michael Ignatieff (Op-Ed, Oct. 10), the people of Serbia were moved to a popular uprising ''for what he did to Serbia: ruining the economy, terrorizing opponents and stealing elections.'' They were not so moved when ''all'' he was doing was ''ethnic cleansing'' in Kosovo and Bosnia.

As we celebrate the overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic, it is important to step back and realize what we are celebrating. As pointed out by Michael Ignatieff (Op-Ed, Oct. 10), the people of Serbia were moved to a popular uprising ''for what he did to Serbia: ruining the economy, terrorizing opponents and stealing elections.'' They were not so moved when ''all'' he was doing was ''ethnic cleansing'' in Kosovo and Bosnia.

If not for the NATO intervention and economic sanctions, with the economic privation in Serbia that resulted, would the populace have felt the need to get rid of this indicted war criminal? It would appear that what we are celebrating is largely a revolt against economic suffering, not against barbarity.
DAVID E. MANDELBAUM Highland Park, N.J., Oct. 11, 2000
